title: Official Blind Review #1
review:
This paper investigates the use of a wavelet transform to provide
the input to convnet in the context of BCI using EEG data.
While the success of the approach is plausible (using time-frequency
transforms as input to nets in audio is quite common), the paper
has a number of issues.

My first concern is that the paper is not well written (many typos,
latex formatting style, sentences too long and hard to parse). This
harms readability of the contribution.

Now regarding the contribution: given the amount of work on this topic
and the marginal difficulty of the contribution, the only way I see
to convince reviewers is to provide a massive empirical evaluation
that proves a clear win on the state-of-the-art. Unfortunately the
paper reports results on only one dataset with no clear improvement.

I would encourage the author(s) to get some help with writing and
conduct a more thorough evaluation. See for example
the community effort on MOAB (Mother of all benchmarks) for BCI
(https://github.com/NeuroTechX/moabb) that aims to provide a
clear and public baseline.

Remarks on text:

- "which is an affordable solution, noninvasive, easy setup, and portability" -> "which is an affordable solution, noninvasive, with easy setup, and portability"

- "state of the art" -> "state-of-the-art" when used adjective

- check difference between \citet and \citep

then I stopped as there are too many.
